creditline: Gift of Edward Duff Balken, Class of 1897
inscribed:
possibly in ink, on verso of wood support: D. Taber for her little neice [sic] Hetty E. Taber 13 months old. New Bedford 5th month 29th 1830
in ink, on verso: Deceased 10th mo 16 1875 in Lincoln VT.

texts.textentryhtml: Born into a large Quaker family, Taber is said to have been introduced to watercolor painting by an elder brother who gave her a box of paints and brushes he brought home from Europe. Both before and after her marriage in 1825, she produced watercolor portraits of her family and friends, offering them as gifts. According to Taber’s inscription on the verso, this engaging large-scale portrait of her niece Mehitable Eddy Taber, nicknamed Hetty, was made on May 29, 1830, when the sitter was thirteen months old. With the exception of a few strokes of watercolor on the face, wrist, and elbow, the artist relied primarily on the paper support to suggest flesh tones.
texts.remarks: Painting on Paper: American Watercolors at Princeton
